title: High-end Italian marketplace, Greek restaurant, luxury shops to replace Neiman Marcus at Copley Place
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Copley Place will replace Neiman Marcus with an Italian marketplace, Greek restaurant, and luxury boutiques.
The space will feature Casa Tua Cucina, Estiatorio Milos, and luxury brands like Dolce & Gabbana and FENDI.
Construction starts this year with phased openings, including retail and dining, expected to complete by 2028.

title: Boston was just named funniest city in the U.S. Is it?
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: Boston named the funniest city in the U.S. by TicketSource, ahead of Washington D.C. and San Francisco.
City cited for strong ticket demand, local comedians, and numerous comedy venues like The Wilbur and Laugh Boston.
Boston's humor also attributed to everyday interactions such as sports bar banter and local vernacular.

title: Mass. snow totals by town: See who got the most from fast-moving overnight system
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: Gloucester tops February 10-11 snow totals in Massachusetts, receiving 6 inches overnight.
Most Massachusetts towns reported snow accumulations between 1 to 3 inches, according to National Weather Service.
Recent snowstorm follows Gloucester's previous 27-inch accumulation from January, highlighting persistent winter weather impacts.

title: $8M South End penthouse in converted church has views of Prudential Center
author: Regina Cole
bullets: The former Concord Baptist Church in Boston's South End now features an $8 million penthouse for sale.
The 3,508-square-foot penthouse includes three bedrooms, 3.5 baths, and direct elevator access to two parking spaces.
The property boasts a cupola with 360-degree views, walnut flooring, and a kitchen with high-end appliances.

title: Recent homes sales in Greater Boston (Feb. 11)
author: The Boston Globe
bullets: In Boston, a one-family row-middle home at 25 Upton St., built in 1861, sold for $4,035,000.
A one-family Colonial home in Arlington at 56 Valentine Road, built in 1950, fetched $2,100,000.
A condo at 11 Joy St. #4, Boston, built in 1899, with 807 sq ft, sold for $1,160,000.

title: Hundreds of students displaced after burst pipe closes UMass Boston dorm
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: A burst sprinkler pipe displaced hundreds at UMass Boston, affecting 50 rooms in East Residence Hall.
The dorm closure left students struggling to find accommodation, with some experiencing homelessness or crowded conditions.
UMass Boston is offering temporary housing and reopening the dining hall while repairs continue on the dorm.

title: Seattle Public Library schools the Boston Public Library with book recommendations for Patriots fans
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Seattle Public Library recommended 35 books to Boston Public Library, following Seahawks' Super Bowl win over Patriots.
Recommendations include Michael Bennett's memoir 'Things That Make White People Uncomfortable' and Maggie Rudd's children's book.
Both libraries participate in 'Books Unbanned,' supporting freedom for teens to read without censorship.

title: State auditor sues Beacon Hill to force compliance with audit
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: State Auditor Diana DiZoglio filed a lawsuit to enforce her authority to audit the Massachusetts State Legislature.
DiZoglio's lawsuit follows 72% voter approval of her audit authority, but faces opposition from Attorney General Andrea Campbell.
House leaders and Senate officials named in the lawsuit argue existing independent audits suffice, suggesting political motives for DiZoglio's actions.

title: Man arrested in Seaport, charged with human trafficking
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Schineider Dave Macean, 23, from West Roxbury, was arrested by Boston police for human trafficking in Seaport.
Macean faces charges including human trafficking, commercial sex acts, and deriving support from prostitution.
The arrest followed an undercover operation near Seaport Boulevard and Thompson Place; arraignment set in South Boston District Court.

title: As Boston residents report daytime coyote sightings, here’s how to stay safe
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Coyote sightings have increased in Boston due to their mating season, which peaks from January through March.
MassWildlife advises residents to keep pets indoors and secure food sources to prevent coyote encounters.
Coyote attacks on humans in Massachusetts are rare, with fewer than 10 incidents in the last 60 years.
